newsitem.title: MOLDOVA: Moldova to turn to "cash privatisation".
newsitem.headline: Moldova to turn to "cash privatisation".

text.p: Moldova has shifted most of its companies into the private sector, and is now turning to a new phase of privatisation to raise money for the government, a senior minister said on Thursday.
"We sought to complete the mass voucher privatisation in 1995-1996, and we will turn to cash privatisation in 1997-1998," Privatisation Minister Ceslav Ciobanu told parliament.
The private sector in Moldova accounts for 60 percent of industrial companies, 70 percent of retail trade and services and 44 percent of construction and transport.
Like many other former communist countries, Moldova distributed free vouchers to its citizens.
Moldovans could use these to buy shares in 2,235 companies, or three out of four of state-run enterprises.
The scheme was seen as socially just but raised no money for the treasury.
The government has started to sell off shares for cash, but has not raised much money so far.
In 1995-1996 the government raised 86 million lei from privatisation, less than half of the 185 million target.
Many companies in Moldova, a former Soviet republic between Ukraine and Romania, are going unsold because of the high asking price coupled with people's poor purchasing power.

The government has pinned its main hopes on finding strategic foreign investors, invited to buy stakes of up to 60 percent in 41 companies in key sectors of the economy. But not a single enterprise has been sold so far.

The high-profile sale of Moldova's tobacco industry to Germany's Reemtsma has fallen apart in mutual recriminations, and the authorities are now planning a new tender which Britain's B.A.T. Industries plc is well placed to win.
In March parliament will consider a privatisation programme for the next two years, which is likely to concentrate on cash sales, attracting foreign investment and restructuring privatised companies.
